citation.article-title: Pseudomonas brenneri sp. nov., a new species isolated from natural mineral waters.

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas brenneri sp. nov.

Pseudomonas brenneri (Bren'ner. i. M.L. masc. gen. n. brenneri of Brenner, in honor of D.J. Brenner, an American microbiologist, for his contributions to the taxonomy of the families Enterobacteriaceae and Legionellaceae)
Cell and colony characteristics
Cells are Gram-negative, asporogeneous, rod-shaped and motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Colonies are smooth on nutrient agar, circular, nonpigmented and hemolytic when grown on blood agar.
Biochemical and physiological characteristics
All strains of P. brenneri produce a fluorescent pigment on both the King B and on S1 medium [18].
They grow at 4°C but not at 41°C.
Arginine dihydrolase, catalase, oxidase, tween esterase, lecithinase, and tributyrin esterase are also produced.
Lysine and ornithine are not decarboxylated.
Cells can reduce nitrate to nitrite, grow at low salt concentrations (0.8% and 3%) but not at the following upper salinities tested 5% and 7%.
Strains do not possess any DNase, coagulase, urease and elastase activities.
Fibrinolysis and acetyl-methylcarbinol (acetoin) tests were negative.
They are able to form levan from sucrose.
Acid is formed from starch.
Cells can grow with presence of 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTZ).
Poly-β-hydroxybutyrate is not accumulated.

Assimilation of carbon compounds Ninety percent or more of the strains utilize the following substrates as sole carbon and energy sources: α-D(+) glucose, β-D(+) fructose, D(+) trehalose, D(+) mannose, D(−) ribose, α-L-rhamnose, D(+) arabitol, L(−) arabitol, xylitol, glycerol, myo-inositol, D-mannitol, adonitol, i-erythritol, mucate, L(−) malate, cis-aconitate, citrate, 2-keto-D-gluconate, Nacetyl-D-glucosamine, D-gluconate, protocatechuate, (−) quinate, benzoate, putrescine, α-aminobutyrate, DL-lactate, caprate, caprylate, succinate, fumarate, glutarate, DL-glycerate, itaconate, 3-hydroxybutyrate, L-aspartate, L-glutamate, L-proline, D-alanine, L-alanine, L-serine, malonate, propionate, L-tyrosine.

The following compounds are not utilized by 90% or more of the strains: L(+) sorbose, α-D(+) melibiose, sucrose, D(+) raffinose, maltotriose, maltose, α-lactose, lactulose, 1-O-methyl-β-galactopyranoside, 1-O-methyl-α-galactopyranoside, D(+) cellobiose, β-gentiobiose, 1-O-methyl-β-D-glucopyranoside, aesculin, L(+) arabinose, D(+) xylose, palatinose, α-L-fucose, D(+) melezitose, dulcitol, D-tagatose, maltitol, D(+) turanose, D-sorbitol, hydroxyquinoline-β-glucuronide, D-lyxose, 1-O-methyl-α-D-glucopyranoside, 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose, D-saccharate, L(+) tartrate, D(−) tartrate, mesotartrate, trans-aconitate, tricarballylate, D-glucuronate, D-galacturonate, 5-keto-D-gluconate, L-tryptophan, phenylacetate, m-hydroxybenzoate, 3-phenylpropionate, m-coumarate, trigonelline, histamine, L-histidine.
Enzymatic tests Ninety percent or more of the strains possess the following enzyme activities: esterase (C4), esteraselipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, phosphatase acide.

None of the strains possess the following enzyme activities: cystine arylamidase, trypsine, α-chymotrypsine, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, N-acethyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase, α-fucosidase.
All strains have been isolated from natural mineral waters.
No clinical significance is known.
The type strain is CFML 97-391T and has been deposited in the Collection de l'Institut Pasteur as CIP 106646T.
The G+C content of the type strain is 58 mol%.
